user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_mv:
```c
int32 OS_mv(const char *src, const char *dest)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* First try rename - this only works if it is on the same filesystem */
    return_code = OS_rename(src, dest);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_cp(src, dest);
        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            OS_remove(src);
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_mv:
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_rename(const char *old, const char *new)
{
    OS_object_iter_t             iter;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    int32                        return_code;
    char                         old_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];
    char                         new_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(old, old_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_TranslatePath(new, new_path);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FileRename_Impl(old_path, new_path);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

        while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
        {
            stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, iter.token);

            if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID && strcmp(stream->stream_name, old) == 0)
            {
                strncpy(stream->stream_name, new, sizeof(stream->stream_name) - 1);
                stream->stream_name[sizeof(stream->stream_name) - 1] = 0;
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_cp(const char *src, const char *dest)
{
    int32     return_code;
    int32     rd_size;
    int32     wr_size;
    int32     wr_total;
    osal_id_t file1;
    osal_id_t file2;
    uint8     copyblock[OS_CP_BLOCK_SIZE];

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(src);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(dest);

    file1       = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    file2       = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    return_code = OS_OpenCreate(&file1, src, OS_FILE_FLAG_NONE, OS_READ_ONLY);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_OpenCreate(&file2, dest, OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE | OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE, OS_WRITE_ONLY);
    }

    while (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        rd_size = OS_read(file1, copyblock, sizeof(copyblock));
        if (rd_size < 0)
        {
            return_code = rd_size;
            break;
        }
        if (rd_size == 0)
        {
            break;
        }
        wr_total = 0;
        while (wr_total < rd_size)
        {
            wr_size = OS_write(file2, &copyblock[wr_total], rd_size - wr_total);
            if (wr_size < 0)
            {
                return_code = wr_size;
                break;
            }
            wr_total += wr_size;
        }
    }

    if (OS_ObjectIdDefined(file1))
    {
        OS_close(file1);
    }
    if (OS_ObjectIdDefined(file2))
    {
        OS_close(file2);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_remove(const char *path)
{
    int32 return_code;
    char  local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, local_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FileRemove_Impl(local_path);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I reviewed all provided code fragments (OS_mv, OS_rename, OS_cp, OS_remove and the int32 typedef). None of the statements are statically unreachable: 

- OS_mv: The flow is conditional but reachable: the initial OS_rename call can succeed or fail; on failure the OS_cp path is executed, and OS_remove(src) is executed only when OS_cp returns success. Each branch is reachable depending on runtime results, so no dead code.

- OS_rename: Path-translation calls are conditional on the previous success code, which is normal error propagation and does not create unreachable code. The object-iterator loop is entered only when return_code == OS_SUCCESS and iterating depends on the iterator API; both the loop body and the post-loop destroy call are reachable when the iterator yields elements or when the initial condition allows entering the loop. No statements are trivially unreachable (there is no code after an unconditional return or break that could never execute).

- OS_cp: The outer while(return_code == OS_SUCCESS) loop is controlled by return_code and contains explicit break conditions (rd_size < 0, rd_size == 0) so the loop and its inner while are reachable and properly terminate. The inner write loop updates wr_total and breaks on write errors; the wr_total += wr_size line is reachable when wr_size >= 0. The cleanup closes are conditional on object-id-defined checks, which are runtime conditions and not statically unreachable.

- OS_remove: Straightforward conditional call after successful path translation; no unreachable code.

- Macros/impl functions (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_TranslatePath, OS_FileRename_Impl, iterator APIs, etc.) could alter control flow at runtime, but based on the provided snippets there are no syntactic constructs that create dead/unreachable code (e.g., code after an unconditional return, infinite loops with no breaks, or mutually exclusive constant conditions). Therefore there are no suspicious fragments to investigate for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 in the supplied code.
